description.narrative:
AWEPA föreslår att implementera ett två-årigt program (2016-2017) för att arbeta med institutionellt kapacitetsbyggande av regionala parlament i Afrika söder om Sahara, framförallt med fokus på de nya Sustainable Development Goals. Programmet kommer att prioritera EALA (East African Legislative Assembly), för deras anvancerade ställning med lagstiftande mandat, och PAP (Pan-African Parliament), för deras kontinentala mandat. Programmet kommer därutöver att arbeta med SADC-PF, ECOWAS-P och CEMAC-P. Programmet är en fortsättning på tidigare femårigt samarbete mellan Sida och AWEPA kring regionala afrikanska parlament och MDG:s.
AWEPA:s program, med titeln ‘Regional African Parliaments in Development: taking up challenges and opportunities of the SDG’s’, har som mål att förbättra regional demokrati genom att stärka de regionala parlamentens ställning, samt öka effektiviteten i arbetet mot SDG:s. Programmet är relevant under Sidas strategi för utvecklingssamarbete i Afrika söder om Sahara genom att de arbetar med ansvarsutkrävande, demokrati och med REC:ar och AU, vilka identifierats som strategiska aktörer för regionalt arbete i Afrika. Programmet är också relevant för Sida i bredare mening genom dess fokus på SDG:s.
Tanken var ursprungligen att programmet skulle vara avsevärt mer omfattande och pågå i fem år. Framförallt på grund av budgetnedskärningar under hösten 2015 behövde Sida omprioritera och i denna process bestämdes att en mycket mindre summa kunde ges till AWEPA, under en kortare period. Diskussionerna landade vid att AWEPA får 6MSEK över en tvåårsperiod, och att Sida därefter antagligen inte kan fortsätta sitt stöd till organisationen. Mot denna bakgrund har extraordinärt stora overhead-kostnader godkänts för programmet, då AWEPA behöver hålla sin organisation och sina partnerskap vid liv.

AWEPA will work with institutional capacity building of regional parliaments in Sub-Saharan Africa. The programme will prioritise EALA (East African Legislative Assembly), for their advanced position with legislative mandate, and PAP (Pan-African Parliament) for their continent-wide mandate. The programme will above this work with SADC-PF, ECOWAS-P and CEMAC-P.
AWEPA's programme, with the titel "Regional African Parliaments in Development: taking up challenges and opportunities of the SDG's" has the objective to improve regional democracy by reinforcing the position of the regional parliaments, and increase the effectiveness in the work toward the SDG's. It is a two year programme for 2016 and 2017.
The programme was initially intended to be of greater scope and over a five year period. Mainly because of budget cuts during the autumn of 2015, Sida had to reprioritise and in this process it was decided that the programme would receive a much smaller support. The discussions ended in a support of 6MSEK over a two year period, and in that Sida after this period probably will not be able to continue to work with AWEPA on regional parliaments. Extraordinarily big overhead costs have therefore been approved for the programme, as AWEPA needto keep its organisation and partnerships alive.
Regional parliaments have enhanced capacity, networks and support to deliver on their mandate.

description.narrative: Reporting for 2016 was received, but not reflected in a statement in Trac. The report includes activities aiming to contribute to strengthen AWEPA's partnerships with the Pan-African Parliament (PAP), the East Africa Legislative Assembly (EALA), the Southern African Development Community Parliamentary Forum (SADC-PF), the Parliament of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the Parliament of the Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa (CEMAC) within the framework of a SDG-program. AWEPA reported that this has resulted in Africa’s continental and regional parliaments making significant improvements by involving civil society more actively in the work of their committees and at the institutional level, putting forward informed opinions on West Africa’s agricultural strategy and training staff on change management. Because of the programme, a series of resolutions, recommendations and declarations were put forward at the regional and continental level to address various areas, ranging from gender equality, institutional strengthening, agriculture, to good governance and development aid. In addition, regional parliaments were at the forefront in advocating for the important role played by national and regional parliaments in achieving and monitoring development indicators.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
